titlePart.text: HOT-GAS OR COMBUSTION-PRODUCT ENGINE PLANTS
GAS-TURBINE PLANTS
AIR INTAKES FOR JET-PROPULSION PLANTS
CONTROLLING FUEL SUPPLY IN AIR-BREATHING JET-PROPULSION PLANTS
titlePart.entryReference: using gas turbines in compression refrigeration plants
using gas-turbine plants in vehicles, see the relevant vehicle classes

noteParagraph.text: Attention is drawn to the notes preceding class .
combustion product or hot gas turbine plants (steam turbine plants );
internal combustion turbines or turbine plants;
turbine plants in which the working fluid is an unheated, pressurised gas (special vapour plants ).
In this sub-class, the term "gas-turbine plants" covers all the above subject-matter and it additionally embraces features of jet-propulsion plants common to gas-turbine plants.

titlePart.text: Gas-turbine plants characterised by the use of hot gases or unheated pressurised gases, as the working fluid
titlePart.entryReference: by the use of combustion products ,

characterised by the type or source of heat, e.g. using nuclear or solar energy
using reheated exhaust gas
Semi-closed cycles
Closed cycles
Gas-turbine plants characterised by the use of combustion products as the working fluid
using exhaust-gas pressure in a pressure exchanger to compress combustion-air
having a turbine driving a compressor
having compressor and turbine passages in a single rotor takes precedence)
the compressor and the turbine being of the radial flow type
the compressor being of the positive-displacement type
the compressor comprising only axial stages
having counter-rotating rotors
the compressor and turbine stages being concentric
the compressor comprising at least one radial stage
of the centripetal type
with another turbine driving output shaft but not driving the compressor
characterised by the arrangement of the combustion chamber in the plant
the combustion chambers being formed at least partly in the turbine rotor
using a special fuel, oxidant, or dilution fluid to generate the combustion products
the fuel or oxidant being gaseous at standard temperature and pressure
the fuel or oxidant being liquid at standard temperature and pressure
the fuel or oxidant being solid or pulverulent, e.g. in slurry or suspension
using a separate gas producer for gasifying the fuel before combustion
Adding water, steam or other fluids to the combustible ingredients or to the working fluid before discharge from the turbine
titlePart.entryReference: heating of air intakes to prevent icing

titlePart.text: Inducing air flow by fluid jet, e.g. ejector action
with recycling of part of the working fluid, i.e. semi-closed cycles with combustion products in the closed part of the cycle
Open cycles
Gas-turbine plants characterised by the working fluid being generated by intermittent combustion
characterised by the arrangement of the combustion chamber in the plant
the combustion chambers being formed at least partly in the turbine rotor
the working fluid being generated in an internal-combustion gas generator of the positive-displacement type having essentially no mechanical power output
titlePart.entryReference: internal-combustion engines with prolonged expansion using exhaust gas turbines

titlePart.text: the gas generator being of the free-piston type
the working fluid forming a resonating or oscillating gas column, i.e. the combustion chambers having no positively actuated valves, e.g. using Helmholtz effect
using valveless combustion chambers
the combustion chambers having inlet or outlet valves, e.g. Holzwarth gas-turbine plants

titlePart.text: Adaptations of gas-turbine plants for special use
Plural gas-turbine plants having a common power output
Gas-turbine plants providing heated or pressurised working fluid for other apparatus, e.g. without mechanical power output
providing compressed gas
the gas being bled from the gas-turbine compressor
supplying working fluid to a user, e.g. a chemical process, which returns working fluid to a turbine of the plant
Turbochargers, i.e. plants for augmenting mechanical power output of internal-combustion piston engines by increase of charge pressure
Gas-turbine plants having means for storing energy, e.g. for meeting peak loads
for storing compressed air
Using the waste heat of gas-turbine plants outside the plants themselves, e.g. gas-turbine power heat plants
titlePart.entryReference: using waste heat as source of energy for refrigeration plants
